newsitem.title: USA: Clinton signals flexibility on school bonds - GFOA.
newsitem.headline: Clinton signals flexibility on school bonds - GFOA.

text.p: President Clinton signalled on Thursday that he may be flexible about how municipalities leverage the $5 billion in school construction seed money he wants Congress to bankroll over the next four years, a key bond lobbyist said.

Clinton, in his proposed fiscal 1998 budget released earlier on Thursday, said the $5 billion fund would support interest subsidies or "similar assistance" designed to let issuers stretch federal dollars by an additional $15 billion over four years to fix crumbling schools.

Catherine Spain, a lobbyist for the Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA), said the "similar assistance" language may be brand new, which means that issuers may be able to tap revolving loan funds or other leveraging mechanisms currently used in the municipal market.

The Administration may be looking at funding alternatives because of concerns that the market would view the federal government as guarantor on any debt resulting from interest subsidies, said one bond market participant, who asked not to be identified.
Also state and local governments are sensitive about any "intrusion" in municipal affairs by the federal government, the source said.

Jim Smith, chief lobbyist for the Council of Infrastructure Financing Authority, said, "We've proposed to the White House that the revolving loan fund mechanism would work much more efficiently" than interest subsidies.

"You'd get a lot more leverage out of it," he said. The federal government could provide financing director to states, which could leverage the funds in the bond market and then make loans back to communities, Smith said.
